Appearance
From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: vëngër

English

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle English venger, vengere, vengeour, vengeur, from Old French vengeor, vengeur.[1] By surface analysis, venge +‎ -er.

Noun

[edit]

venger (plural vengers)

  1. Obsolete form of avenger.
    • 1590, Edmund Spenser, “Book I, Canto III”, in The Faerie Queene. […], London: […] [John Wolfe] for William Ponsonbie, →OCLC, page 37:
      His bleeding hart is in the vengers hand, / VVho ſtreight him rent in thouſand peeces ſmall, […]
    • 1891, Rudyard Kipling, The Mutiny of the Mavericks:
      And the hand of the venger shall never be stayed / Till his race, faith, and speech are a dream of the past

See also

[edit]
  • revenger
  • avenger

References

[edit]
  • “venger”, in Webster’s Revised Unabridged Dictionary, Springfield, Mass.: G. & C. Merriam, 1913, →OCLC.
  1. ^ “venǧer(e, n.”, in MED Online, Ann Arbor, Mich.: University of Michigan, 2007.

Anagrams

[edit]
  • greven

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Middle French venger, vengier, from Old French vengier, from Latin vindicāre.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /vɑ̃.ʒe/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)
  • Rhymes: -e
  • Homophones: vengé, vengeai, vengée, vengées, vengés, vengez

Verb

[edit]

venger

  1. to avenge, to take revenge (upon)

Conjugation

[edit]

This is a regular -er verb, but the stem is written venge- before endings that begin with -a- or -o- (to indicate that the -g- is a "soft" /ʒ/ and not a "hard" /ɡ/). This spelling change occurs in all verbs in -ger, such as neiger and manger.

Norwegian Nynorsk

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • vengar

Noun

[edit]

venger m

  1. indefinite plural of veng

Old French

[edit]

Verb

[edit]

venger

  1. alternative form of vengier

Conjugation

[edit]

This verb conjugates as a first-group verb ending in -er. In the present tense an extra supporting e is needed in the first-person singular indicative and throughout the singular subjunctive, and the third-person singular subjunctive ending -t is lost. In addition, g becomes j before an a or an o to keep the /dʒ/ sound intact. Old French conjugation varies significantly by date and by region. The following conjugation should be treated as a guide.

    Conjugation of venger (see also Appendix:Old French verbs)
simple compound
infinitive venger avoir vengé
gerund en venjant gerund of avoir + past participle
present participle venjant
past participle vengé
person singular plural
first second third first second third
indicative jo tu il nos vos il
